FIGREF0.text: acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2)[1]. Since its first76 appearance and reporting in December 2019, it has infected over 462,684 cases and 77 caused 20,834 death as of 26 th March 2020. (WHO Coronavirus disease situation 78 reports). Patients with COVID-19 may develop acute respiratory distress syndrome 79 and occasionally may progress to multiorgan failure[2]. Latest reports suggest that for 80 COVID-19 the hospitalization rate is 20.7-31.4%, ICU admission rate is 4.9-11.5%, 81 and the case-fatality rate is 1.8-3.4%[3]. It is expected that COVID-19 will still rise 82 and there will be a growing demand for intensive care[4]. Quick identification of 83 potential critical patients is important in the management of this disease to prioritize 84 health-care resources which is under strain in practically every part of the world[5, 6]. 85 Cytotoxic T lymphocytes and natural killer cells are necessary for the control of viral 86 infection. A functional exhaustion of antiviral lymphocytes is reported in COVID-19 87 patients[7, 8]. However, there is still limited evidence for the predictive role of 88 lymphocyte count in predicting the severity of COVID-19. Herein, we reviewed all 89 the literature of COVID-19 from December 2019 to 22 March to explore the possible 90 role of lymphocyte counts in differentiating between severe and non-severe 91 COVID-19 patients, so as to find out a simple tool for quick identification of potential 92 critical patients which will help with the clinical management of this new disease.

Following terms and their relative 102 variants were used for literature search: "COVID-19" OR "2019 novel coronavirus 103 infection" OR "coronavirus disease 2019" OR "2019 novel coronavirus disease" OR 104 "coronavirus 2019" OR "2019-nCoV" OR "SARS-CoV-2" OR "COVID19" OR 105 "coronavirus disease-19". 106 The title, abstract and full text of all documents identified according to this search 107 strategy were then screened by two investigators (M.M and QW.Z). After removing the duplicate records, 1596 138 studies were retained. Furthermore, 1548 studies were excluded as they were not 139 relevant to current meta-analysis. Full text of the remaining 48 articles was assessed 140 for eligibility, 35 of which were removed for various reasons. Eventually 13 studies 141 (11 in English and 2 in Chinese) [9-20]were included in analysis (Figure 1). The 142 characteristics and demographic data of the included studies are shown in table 1. As 143 all the studies included in this meta-analysis were retrospective case-series, the 144 calculation of sample size was not reported. Most studies reported the follow-up 145 period inadequately. As a result, the overall quality of literatures included in this study 146was not high, with MINORS scores from 10-13.

FIGREF8.text: 2020 published in English language, showing that patients with severe 185 COVID-19 displayed a lymphocyte count reduction compared with non-severe 186 COVID-19 group. Lymphopenia, defined as a lymphocyte count of less than 187 1.5×10 9 /L is associated with a 3-fold increased risk of severe COVID-19 infection. 188 The lack of awareness of severity of disease in early stage of COVID-19 coupled with 189 the high infectivity of the virus has led to a dramatic increase in the number of 190 patients and relative high fatality rates world-wide. A cheap, easily acquired 191 biomarker is needed to identify severe disease among hospitalized patients at early 192 stage. According to our results, lymphocyte count and lymphopenia may serve as a 193 rapid tool that can quickly identify COVID-19 patients with more severe clinical 194 presentation. Previous studies observed that lymphopenia is a common observation in 195 patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) caused by SARS virus with 196 reported prevalence of 69.6%-54%[22, 23]. Lymphopenia is quite notable in SARS 197 infection[24]. SARS infection may either directly suppress bone marrow or induce an 198 immune-mediated destruction of lymphocytes resulting in lymphopenia [25]. 199 SARS-COV-2 might share the similar inner mechanism with SARS virus, including 200 direct infect and destruct lymphocytes [26] and cytokine-mediated lymphocyte 201 destruction [27-29]. 202 The main drawback of this meta-analysis is the heterogeneity of included cases. All 203 the included studies were retrospective case series as no data from either prospective J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 13 observation study or randomized trials are available. The patients in different studies 205 might be at different stages of disease. Furthermore, the different definition of 206 severity of COVID-19 and the discrepancy in the cut-offs for lymphopenia, which can 207 be partially mitigated by considering lymphocyte count of less than 1.5×10 9 /L as 208 lymphopenia, might be one of the reasons for the heterogeneity.

FIGREF10.text: 210 fluctuations of lymphocyte counts on the disease course which is significant to the 211 detection of COVID-19 clinical course. So, it is early to draw a conclusion that 212 lymphopenia is related to deterioration of COVID-19. A recent research with small 213 sample-size showed the dynamic changes of lymphocyte counts could predict the 214 deterioration of COVID-19, yet studies with large sample size are still lacking in this 215 field[30]. 216 Due to the extremely rapid spread of COVID-19 world-wide, waiting for the results 217 from prospective studies will delay the understanding of this novel disease as a result 218 of which there may be a delay in the clinical management of patients. Even in the 219 light of all these limitations, the result of this meta-analysis shows that the presence of 220 lymphopenia in the evolution COVID-19 may help to rapidly identify patients at risk 221 of severe pneumonia and worse outcomes. Further studies should focus on the 222 time-line of lymphopenia development, severity of COVID-19 and ARDS, which may 223 confirm our findings about the relationship between lymphopenia and severity of 224 COVID-19.
